It follows, for example, that if \(f(t)\) is defined over \( (-\pi, \pi )\) as one of the following functions \(t^3\) or \(\dfrac{1}{t-4}\) or \( 3t + 2\) and \( f(t+2\pi) = f(t) \), then \(f(t)\) can indeed be represented as a Fourier series as each function satisfies the Dirichlet conditions.

On the other hand, if, over \( (-\pi, \pi )\), \(f(t)\) is \( \dfrac{1}{t}\) or \( \dfrac{1}{t-2} \) or \( \tan t\) then \( f(t)\) cannot be expanded in a Fourier series because each of these functions has an infinite discontinuity within \( (-\pi, \pi )\).

If the Dirichlet conditions are satisfied at a point \(t = t_0\) where \(f(t)\) is continuous then, as we would expect, the Fourier series at \(t_0\) given by \[ \dfrac{a_0}{2} + \sum _{n=1}^\infty \left\{ a_n \cos \left( \dfrac{2n\pi t_0}{T} \right) + b_n \sin \left( \dfrac{2n\pi t_0}{T} \right) \right\} \hspace{1cm} \text{converges to the function value } f(t_0) \] At a point, say \(t = t_1\), at which \(f(t)\) has a discontinuity then the series \[ \dfrac{a_0}{2} + \sum _{n=1}^\infty \left\{ a_n \cos \left( \dfrac{2n\pi t_1}{T} \right) + b_n \sin \left( \dfrac{2n\pi t_1}{T} \right) \right\} \hspace{1cm} \text{converges to } \dfrac{1}{2} \{ f(t_{1-}) + f(t_{1+})\}   \] where \(f (t_{1-})\) is the limit of \(f(t)\) as \(t\) approaches \(t_1\) from the left, and \(f (t_{1+})\) is the limit of \(f(t)\) as \(t\) approaches \(t_1\) from the right as shown in the Figure below.


 

Key Point

If Dirichlet conditions are satisfied then at a point of continuity \(t = t_0\)

\[ f(t_0) = \dfrac{a_0}{2} + \sum _{n=1}^\infty \left\{ a_n \cos \left( \dfrac{2n\pi t_0}{T} \right) + b_n \sin \left( \dfrac{2n\pi t_0}{T} \right) \right\} \] whereas at a point of discontinuity \(t = t_1\) the Fourier series converges to the average of the two limiting values \[ \dfrac{1}{2} \{ f(t_{1-}) + f(t_{1+}) \}= \dfrac{a_0}{2} + \sum _{n=1}^\infty \left\{ a_n \cos \left( \dfrac{2n\pi t_1}{T} \right) + b_n \sin \left( \dfrac{2n\pi t_1}{T} \right) \right\} \hspace{1cm} \]
